P.title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially held in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by a recognized authority such as the United Nations or the European Union. The term 'international sanctions' refers to restrictions imposed on a country that may include trade embargoes, financial restrictions, or other punitive measures aimed at influencing the country's policies. The event must be part of the official Formula 1 calendar and must take place as a full race, not a demonstration or exhibition. In case of multiple races, the first instance of such a race will determine the resolution. If the country is removed from sanctions after the race is announced but before the race occurs, it will still count towards a Yes resolution.

not_P.title: Will no Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2030?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, no Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially held in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by a recognized authority such as the United Nations or the European Union. The term 'international sanctions' refers to restrictions imposed on a country that may include trade embargoes, financial restrictions, or other punitive measures aimed at influencing the country's policies. The event must be part of the official Formula 1 calendar and must take place as a full race, not a demonstration or exhibition. In case of multiple races, the first instance of such a race will determine the resolution. If the country is removed from sanctions after the race is announced but before the race occurs, it will still count towards a No resolution.

P.title: Will Ukraine achieve a membership action plan with NATO by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Ukraine is officially granted a Membership Action Plan (MAP) by NATO. The decision must be confirmed through an official NATO announcement or documentation. The criteria for a MAP include Ukraine's demonstrated commitment to the principles of democracy, individual liberty, and the rule of law, as well as its ability to contribute to NATO's collective defense. Any interim agreements or discussions will not count towards this resolution unless they culminate in an official MAP grant. The resolution will also account for any significant political changes or events that may affect NATO's decision-making process regarding Ukraine's membership aspirations.

not_P.title: Will Ukraine not achieve a membership action plan with NATO by 2025?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Ukraine is not officially granted a Membership Action Plan (MAP) by NATO. The decision must be confirmed through an official NATO announcement or documentation. The criteria for a MAP include Ukraine's demonstrated commitment to the principles of democracy, individual liberty, and the rule of law, as well as its ability to contribute to NATO's collective defense. Any interim agreements or discussions will not count towards this resolution unless they culminate in an official MAP grant. The resolution will also account for any significant political changes or events that may affect NATO's decision-making process regarding Ukraine's membership aspirations.

P.title: Will the World Health Organization declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares a global health emergency specifically related to diseases that are directly attributable to climate change. The declaration must be made in a formal statement or report from the WHO and must identify specific diseases that are exacerbated by climate change, such as vector-borne diseases (e.g., malaria, dengue), respiratory diseases (e.g., asthma, allergies), and waterborne diseases (e.g., cholera). The declaration should be based on scientific evidence and consensus from the global health community, including input from epidemiologists and climate scientists. The resolution will not count declarations that are vague or general in nature without specific reference to climate-related diseases.

not_P.title: Will the World Health Organization not declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the World Health Organization (WHO) does not officially declare a global health emergency specifically related to diseases that are directly attributable to climate change. The absence of a declaration must be noted in a formal statement or report from the WHO and must not identify specific diseases that are exacerbated by climate change, such as vector-borne diseases (e.g., malaria, dengue), respiratory diseases (e.g., asthma, allergies), and waterborne diseases (e.g., cholera). The lack of declaration should be based on scientific evidence and consensus from the global health community, including input from epidemiologists and climate scientists. The resolution will not count declarations that are vague or general in nature without specific reference to climate-related diseases.

The declaration should be based on scientific evidence and consensus from the global health community, including input from epidemiologists and climate scientists. The resolution will not count declarations that are vague or general in nature without specific reference to climate-related diseases.

P.title: Will the US government increase funding for nuclear safety research by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US government has officially increased funding for nuclear safety research compared to the funding levels of 2024. The increase must be documented in an official budget proposal or appropriations bill passed by Congress. The increase must be at least 10% above the 2024 funding level for nuclear safety research as defined by the Department of Energy and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Any funding increases that are temporary, one-time allocations, or related to specific projects without ongoing commitment do not count towards this resolution.

not_P.title: Will the US government not increase funding for nuclear safety research by 2025?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US government has not officially increased funding for nuclear safety research compared to the funding levels of 2024. The increase must be documented in an official budget proposal or appropriations bill passed by Congress. The increase must be less than 10% above the 2024 funding level for nuclear safety research as defined by the Department of Energy and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Any funding increases that are temporary, one-time allocations, or related to specific projects without ongoing commitment do not count towards this resolution.

P.title: Will there be a major public safety incident related to nuclear facilities in the US before 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, any of the following occurs: (1) a significant nuclear incident classified as a Level 3 or higher on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES) occurs at a nuclear facility in the US, resulting in public exposure to radiation or a public safety alert; (2) a major security breach at a nuclear facility that leads to a credible threat to public safety, as reported by a reputable news source (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post); (3) an event causing a substantial evacuation or emergency response related to a nuclear facility, officially recognized by government agencies such as the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). Minor incidents or routine safety drills do not count towards this resolution.

not_P.title: Will there be no major public safety incident related to nuclear facilities in the US before 2025?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, none of the following occurs: (1) a significant nuclear incident classified as a Level 3 or higher on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES) occurs at a nuclear facility in the US, resulting in public exposure to radiation or a public safety alert; (2) a major security breach at a nuclear facility that leads to a credible threat to public safety, as reported by a reputable news source (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post); (3) an event causing a substantial evacuation or emergency response related to a nuclear facility, officially recognized by government agencies such as the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). Minor incidents or routine safety drills do not count towards this resolution.

P.title: Will any international sporting event be held in a country under sanctions by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, any international sporting event (as defined by the International Olympic Committee or FIFA) is held in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by the United Nations or the European Union. The event must be officially recognized and sanctioned by the relevant international sporting federation. For the purposes of this question, 'sanctions' refer to any economic, trade, or diplomatic restrictions imposed on a country. Temporary or unofficial events do not count towards this resolution.

not_P.title: Will no international sporting event be held in a country under sanctions by 2025?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, no international sporting event (as defined by the International Olympic Committee or FIFA) is held in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by the United Nations or the European Union. P.title: Will any state-level legislation regarding nuclear safety standards be enacted before 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, any U.S. state enacts legislation that establishes or amends nuclear safety standards. The legislation must be officially documented and publicly available. The criteria for 'nuclear safety standards' include regulations related to the construction, operation, and decommissioning of nuclear facilities, as well as safety protocols for the handling of nuclear materials. Legislation that is merely proposed or under consideration will not count. The resolution will reference the official state legislative records or reputable news sources that report on the enactment of such legislation.

not_P.title: Will no state-level legislation regarding nuclear safety standards be enacted before 2025?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, no U.S. state enacts legislation that establishes or amends nuclear safety standards. The legislation must be officially documented and publicly available. The criteria for 'nuclear safety standards' include regulations related to the construction, operation, and decommissioning of nuclear facilities, as well as safety protocols for the handling of nuclear materials. Legislation that is merely proposed or under consideration will not count. The resolution will reference the official state legislative records or reputable news sources that report on the enactment of such legislation.

P.title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled to take place in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by recognized authorities such as the United Nations, the European Union, or the United States. The term 'international sanctions' refers to restrictions imposed on a country by the international community, which may include trade restrictions, financial embargoes, and travel bans. The hosting of the Grand Prix must be confirmed by an official announcement from Formula 1 or the relevant governing body. If the event is canceled or relocated for any reason, this question will resolve as No. Temporary or unofficial races do not count towards this resolution.

not_P.title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix not be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is not officially scheduled to take place in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by recognized authorities such as the United Nations, the European Union, or the United States. The term 'international sanctions' refers to restrictions imposed on a country by the international community, which may include trade restrictions, financial embargoes, and travel bans. The hosting of the Grand Prix must be confirmed by an official announcement from Formula 1 or the relevant governing body. If the event is canceled or relocated for any reason, this question will resolve as No. Temporary or unofficial races do not count towards this resolution.
